sen.j: 上杉 朝定（うえすぎ ともさだ）
sen.e: Tomosada UESUGI
Tomosada UESUGI
Tomosada UESUGI

sen.j: 南北朝時代の人物。
sen.e: Tomosada UESUGI was a person who lived in the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties.
Tomosada UESUGI was a person who lived in the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties.
Tomosada UESUGI was a person who lived in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.
sen.cmt: 南北朝時代→統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 二橋上杉家（八条上杉家、扇谷上杉家の前身）当主。
sen.e: He was the head of the Futahashi/Nihashi (二橋)-Uesugi family (the origin of the Hachijo-Uesugi and Ogigayatsu-Uesugi families).
He was the head of the Futahashi/Nihashi (二橋)-Uesugi family (the origin of the Hachijo-Uesugi and Ogigayatsu-Uesugi families).
He was the head of the Futahashi/Nihashi (二橋)-Uesugi family (the origin of the Hachijo-Uesugi and Ogigayatsu-Uesugi families).

sen.j: 戦国時代の人物。
sen.e: Tomosada UESUGI was a person who lived in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).
He lived in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), and was the head of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family.
Tomosada UESUGI was a person who lived in the Sengoku period (Period of Warring States).
sen.cmt: 次の文とまとめて訳されていますが、仕様書に基づき、原文一文に対して一つの訳文になるように修正しました。Sengoku Period→Sengoku periodとしました。

sen.j: 扇谷上杉家当主。
sen.e: He was the head of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family.
He was the head of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family.
He was the head of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family.
sen.cmt: 前の文とまとめて訳されていますが、仕様書に基づき、原文一文に対して一つの訳文になるように修正しました。

sen.j: 戦国時代の人物。
sen.e: Tomosada UESUGI was a person who lived in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).
He lived in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), and was the head of the Sanponji-Uesugi family.
Tomosada UESUGI was a person who lived in the Sengoku period (Period of Warring States).
sen.cmt: 次の文とまとめて訳されていますが、仕様書に基づき、原文一文に対して一つの訳文になるように修正しました。Sengoku Period→Sengoku periodとしました。

sen.j: 山本寺上杉家当主。
sen.e: He was the head of the Sanponji-Uesugi family.
He was the head of the Sanponji-Uesugi family.
He was the head of the Sanponji-Uesugi family.
sen.cmt: 前の文とまとめて訳されていますが、仕様書に基づき、原文一文に対して一つの訳文になるように修正しました。

tit.e: Tomosada UESUGI (of the Futahashi/Nihashi (二橋)-Uesugi family)
Tomosada UESUGI (of the Futahashi/Nihashi (二橋)-Uesugi family)

sen.j: 上杉 朝定（うえすぎ ともさだ）は、南北朝時代 (日本)の武将。
sen.e: Tomosada UESUGI was a warlord who lived in the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties (of Japanese history).
Tomosada UESUGI was a warlord who lived in the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties.
Tomosada UESUGI was a warlord who lived in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.
sen.cmt: 南北朝時代→統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 元享元年（1321年）、上杉重顕の子として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born the son of Shigeaki UESUGI in 1321.
He was born the son of Shigeaki UESUGI in 1321.
He was born the son of Shigeaki UESUGI in 1321.

sen.j: 父の重顕から家督を継いだ。
sen.e: He took over the headship of the family from his father, Shigeaki.
He suceeded his father, Shigeaki, as head of the family.
He suceeded his father, Shigeaki, as head of the family.

sen.j: 足利尊氏・足利直義兄弟に仕え、京において室町幕府の要職（丹後国守護・引付頭人等）にあった。
sen.e: He served Takauji ASHIKAGA and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA, who were brothers, and held important posts (such as military governorship of Tango Province and judge) in the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) while residing in Kyoto.

He served Takauji ASHIKAGA and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA, who were brothers, and held important posts (such as the military governorship of Tango Province, judicial appointments, etc.) in the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) while residing in Kyoto.

He served Takauji ASHIKAGA and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA, who were brothers, and held important posts (such as the military governorship of Tango Province, judicial appointments, etc.) in the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) while residing in Kyoto.

sen.j: 高師直とともに尊氏の執事を務めていたこともあるが、観応の擾乱が勃発すると直義方につき尊氏・師直と戦った。
sen.e: In his earlier days, he served, along with KO no Moronao, as a steward at Takauji; however, he took Tadayoshi's side upon the outbreak of the Kanno Disturbance, and fought against Takauji and Moronao.
He had also served, along with KO no Moronao, as a steward to Takauji; however, he sided withTadayoshi at the outbreak of the Kanno Disturbance, fighting against Takauji and Moronao.
He had also served, along with KO no Moronao, as a steward to Takauji; however, he sided with Tadayoshi at the outbreak of the Kanno Disturbance, fighting against Takauji and Moronao.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを消去、スペース追加

sen.j: ただし、同じ直義方であった一族の上杉重能・上杉憲顕とは関係が思わしくなかったらしい。
sen.e: It seems, however, that Tomosada did not get along with Shigeyoshi UESUGI or Noriaki UESUGI, each of whom took Tadayoshi's side as Tomosada did.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It seems, however, that Tomosada did not get along with Shigeyoshi UESUGI or Noriaki UESUGI, each of whom had also sided with Tadayoshi.
It seems, however, that Tomosada did not get along with Shigeyoshi UESUGI or Noriaki UESUGI, each of whom had also sided with Tadayoshi.

sen.j: 尊氏方への接近を疑わせる行動も取っている。
sen.e: Actually, he took such actions as indicate his approaches to Takauji's side.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処訳文の自然な流れを作るために、訳文の文頭に"Actually"を配置しました。
sen.e: In fact, he also took actions that might be seen as indicating that he sided with Takauji.
In fact, he also took actions that might be seen as indicating that he sided with Takauji.

sen.j: 例えば、乱勃発後に尊氏の嫡男・足利義詮が朝定邸を訪問して会談する（観応元年7月28日『祇園執行日記』）など。
sen.e: For instance, Tomosada had a talk with Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA, Takauji's eldest son, at Tomosada's residence after the outbreak of the disturbance (on July 28, 1350) ("Gion Shigyonikki" (documents containing records of affairs and Buddhist services at Yasaka Shrine)).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For instance, Tomosada met with Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA, Takauji's eldest son, who had visitedTomosada's residence after the outbreak of the disturbance (on July 28, 1350) ("Gion Shigyonikki" (documents containing records of affairs and Buddhist services at Yasaka Shrine)).

For instance, Tomosada met with Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA, Takauji's eldest son, who had visited Tomosada's residence after the outbreak of the disturbance (on September 8, 1350, "Gion Shigyonikki" (documents containing records of affairs and Buddhist services at Yasaka-jinja Shrine)).
sen.cmt: スペース追加、カッコを修正、Yasaka-jinja Shrineとしました。July 28→September 8に変更しました。

sen.j: 正平7年/観応3年（1352年）、信濃国において没した。
sen.e: In 1352, Tomosada died in Shinano Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Tomosada died in Shinano Province in 1352.
Tomosada died in Shinano Province in 1352.

sen.j: 死因は病没とも戦死ともいわれはっきりしない。
sen.e: Opinion is divided on the cause of his death: some say he died of illness, and others say he was killed in battle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Opinion is divided on the cause of his death: some say he died of illness, and others say he was killed in battle.
Opinion is divided on the cause of his death: some say he died of illness, and others say he was killed in battle.

sen.j: 享年32。
sen.e: He was 32 year old.
He was 32 year old.
He was 32 year old.

tit.j: 上杉朝定（山本寺上杉家）

sen.j: 上杉 朝定（うえすぎ ともさだ）は、室町時代中期の武将。
sen.e: Tomosada UESUGI was a warlord who lived in the mid-Muromachi Period.
Tomosada UESUGI was a warlord who lived in the mid-Muromachi Period.
Tomosada UESUGI was a warlord who lived in the mid-Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: Periodの頭文字を小文字に修正

sen.j: 越後国守護である上杉家の分家の一つ山本寺上杉家の祖とされる。
sen.e: He is assumed to be the founder of the Sanponji-Uesugi family, one of the branches of the Uesugi family that held the office of military governorship of Echigo Province.
He is assumed to be the founder of the Sanponji-Uesugi family, one of the branches of the Uesugi family that held the office of the military governorship of Echigo Province.
He is assumed to be the founder of the Sanponji-Uesugi family, one of the branches of the Uesugi family that held the office of the military governorship of Echigo Province.

sen.j: 不動山城を築いたのは朝定とも、朝定の子とされる定種とも云われる。
sen.e: Some say Fudosan Castle was built by Tomosada; however, others say it was built by Sadatane, who is assumed to be Tomosada's son.
Some sources claim that Fudosan Castle was built by Tomosada; however, others claim that it was built by Sadatane, who is assumed to have been Tomosada's son.
Some sources claim that Fudosan-jo Castle was built by Tomosada; however, others claim that it was built by Sadatane, who is assumed to have been Tomosada's son.

sen.j: 山本寺上杉家の系譜ははっきり分かっておらず、戦国時代 (日本)に長尾氏に仕えた上杉定長や上杉孝長（景長）などとの続柄は不明である。
sen.e: The genealogy of the Sanponji-Uesugi family has not been made clear; therefore, relationships to Sadanaga UESUGI or Takanaga (Kagenaga) UESUGI, who served the Nagao clan in the Sengoku Period (of Japanese history) are unknown.

The genealogy of the Sanponji-Uesugi family is not clear; therefore, it is not known whether they were related to Sadanaga UESUGI or Takanaga (Kagenaga) UESUGI, who served the Nagao clan in the Sengoku Period.
sen.cmt: ok, but the confusion incurred prior to this passage needs to be cleared away.
sen.e: The genealogy of the Sanponji-Uesugi family is not clear; therefore, it is not known whether they were related to Sadanaga UESUGI or Takanaga (Kagenaga) UESUGI, who served the Nagao clan in the Sengoku period.
sen.cmt: Periodの頭文字を小文字に修正

sen.j: 上杉 朝定（うえすぎ ともさだ）は、武蔵の戦国大名。
sen.e: Tomosada UESUGI was daimyo (Japanese feudal warlord) in the Sengoku Period, who ruled Musashi Province.
Tomosada UESUGI was a daimyo (a feudal warlord) who ruled Musashi Province during the Sengoku Period.
Tomosada UESUGI was a daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) who ruled Musashi Province during the Sengoku period.
sen.cmt: 統一リストより、daimyo (Japanese feudal warlord)→daimyo (Japanese territorial lord)に修正、Periodの頭文字を小文字に修正

sen.j: 扇谷上杉家の事実上最後の当主である。
sen.e: He was the de facto final head of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family.
He was the de facto final head of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family.
He was the de facto final head of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family.

sen.j: 大永5年（1525年）、上杉朝興の子として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born the son of Tomoki UESUGI in 1525.
He was born the son of Tomoki UESUGI in 1525.
He was born the son of Tomoki UESUGI in 1525.

sen.j: 天文6年（1537年）4月に父が死去したため、家督を継いで当主となる。
sen.e: After the death of his father in April 1525, he took over as the head of the family.
After the death of his father in April 1525, he suceeded his father as head of the family.
After the death of his father in May 1525, he suceeded his father as head of the family.

sen.j: ところが若年の朝定が家督相続したのを好機と見た北条氏綱に7月には河越城を攻められ、朝定は敗走した。
sen.e: However, Ujitsuna HOJO viewed the succession to the headship by young Tomosada as a friend and attacked Kawagoe Castle in July, and Tomosada was routed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Ujitsuna HOJO, however, viewed the succession by the young Tomosada to the head of the family as an opportune moment, and launched an attack on Kawagoe Castle in July, routingTomosada.
Ujitsuna HOJO, however, viewed the succession by the young Tomosada to the head of the family as an opportune moment, and launched an attack on Kawagoe-jo Castle in August, routing Tomosada.
sen.cmt: Kawagoe-jo Castleとし、スペース追加July→Augustに変更しました。

sen.j: 以後は松山城 (武蔵国)を居城とした。
sen.e: Thereafter, Tomosada resided in Matsuyama Castle in Musashi Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Tomosada subsequently took up residence at Matsuyama Castle, in Musashi Province.
Tomosada subsequently took up residence at Matsuyama-jo Castle, in Musashi Province.

sen.j: そして北条氏に対抗するため、武蔵国橘樹郡片倉・神大寺に城（神大寺城）を築いている。
sen.e: He built a castle at Kandaiji, Katakura, Tachibana-gun in Musashi Province (Kandaiji Castle) in order to counteract the Hojo clan.
Then he built a castle at Kandaiji, Katakura, Tachibana-gun in Musashi Province (Kandaiji Castle) as a forification against the Hojo clan.
Then he built a castle at Kandaiji, Katakura, Tachibana-gun in Musashi Province (Kandaiji-jo Castle) as a forification against the Hojo clan.

sen.j: 天文10年（1541年）、長年抗争していた宿敵・山内上杉家の上杉憲政と和睦し、北条氏康に対抗する。
sen.e: In 1541, Tomosada made peace with Norimasa UESUGI of the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family, his old enemy with whom he had been in conflict for years, and counteracted Ujiyasu HOJO.

In 1541, Tomosada made peace with Norimasa UESUGI of the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family, an old enemy with whom he had been in conflict for years, whereby he was able to counter potential aggression by Ujiyasu HOJO.

In 1541, Tomosada made peace with Norimasa UESUGI of the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family, an old enemy with whom he had been in conflict for years, whereby he was able to counter potential aggression by Ujiyasu HOJO.

sen.j: 天文14年（1545年）には駿河国の今川義元と連携し、上杉憲政や古河公方の足利晴氏らと連合した8万の大軍で河越城を攻める。
sen.e: In 1545, he allied with Norimasa UESUGI, Haruuji ASHIKAGA (one of Kogakubo (descendants of one of the Ashikaga families that held the office of the Kanto district administrator), and others to assemble vast allied forces consisting of 80 thousand soldiers, and attacked Kawagoe Castle with this force in cooperation with Yoshimoto IMAGAWA who ruled Suruga Province.

In 1545, he entered into an alliance with Norimasa UESUGI, Haruuji ASHIKAGA (one of the Kogakubo, who were descendants of one of the Ashikaga families and held the office of the regional administrator in Kanto), and others to assemble a vast allied force consisting of some 80 thousand soldiers, and proceeded to attack Kawagoe Castle in concert with Yoshimoto IMAGAWA, the ruler of Suruga Province.

In 1545, he entered into an alliance with Norimasa UESUGI, Haruuji ASHIKAGA (one of the Kogakubo, who were descendants of one of the Ashikaga families and held the office of the regional administrator in Kanto), and others to assemble a vast allied force consisting of some 80 thousand soldiers, and proceeded to attack Kawagoe-jo Castle in concert with Yoshimoto IMAGAWA, the ruler of Suruga Province.

sen.j: 河越城主北条綱成の善戦に遭うものの、落城寸前にまで追い込んだ。
sen.e: Although Tsunashige HOJO, the lord of Kawagoe Castle, put up a good fight, the castle was about to be surrendered.

Though Tsunashige HOJO, the lord of Kawagoe Castle, put up a fight, the castle was on the brink of falling to the enemy on April 29, 1546, when Ujiysasu, who had made haste for Kawagoe Castle intending to attack the enemy from the rear, launched a suprise assault on the allied forces.
Though Tsunashige HOJO, the lord of Kawagoe-jo Castle, put up a fight, the castle was on the brink of falling to the enemy.
sen.cmt: Kawagoe-jo Castleとしました。次の文とまとめて訳されていますが、仕様書に基づき、原文一文に対して一つの訳文になるように修正しました。

sen.j: しかし天文15年（1546年）4月20日、河越城の後詰にかけつけた氏康の奇襲に遭った。
sen.e: On April 29, 1546, however, the allied forces encountered a surprise raid of Ujiyasu, who rushed to Kawagoe Castle to attack the enemy from the rear.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On April 29, 1546, however, the allied forces encountered a surprise raid of Ujiyasu, who rushed to Kawagoe Castle to attack the enemy from the rear.
On May 29, 1546, however, Ujiyasu, who had made haste for Kawagoe-jo Castle intending to attack the enemy from the rear, launched a suprise assault on the allied forces.
sen.cmt: 前の文とまとめて訳されていますが、仕様書に基づき、原文一文に対して一つの訳文になるように修正しました。原文の内容に沿うよう、文章を一部修正、Kawagoe-jo Castleとしました。April →Mayに変更しました。

sen.j: 河越城の戦い（いわゆる河越夜戦）で扇谷上杉軍は善戦するも当主朝定は討死、他の連合軍は四散し河越城奪還の夢は砕かれた。
sen.e: In the Battle of Kawagoe Castle (so-called the night battle of Kawagoe), the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi force put up a god fight, but Tomosada, the head of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family, died on the battlefield and the remains of the allied forces were scattered; thus, Tomosada's dream of recapturing Kawagoe Castle were shattered.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Battle of Kawagoe Castle (the so-called Night Battle of Kawagoe), though the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi force fought bravely, Tomosada, the head of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family, died on the battlefield, and the remains of the allied forces were scattered, shattering Tomosada's dream of recapturing Kawagoe Castle.

In the Battle of Kawagoe-jo Castle (the so-called Night Battle of Kawagoe), though the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi force fought bravely, Tomosada, the head of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family, died on the battlefield, and the remains of the allied forces were scattered, shattering Tomosada's dream of recapturing Kawagoe-jo Castle.

sen.j: 享年22。
sen.e: Tomosada was 22 years old.
Tomosada was 22 years old.
Tomosada was 22 years old.

sen.j: 上杉朝定の死により、扇谷上杉家は断絶した。
sen.e: The death of Tomosada UESUGI resulted in the extinction of the Ogigayatsu-UESUGI family.
The death of Tomosada UESUGI resulted in the extinction of the Ogigayatsu-UESUGI line.
The death of Tomosada UESUGI resulted in the extinction of the Ogigayatsu-UESUGI line.

sen.j: 一時、扇谷家庶流筋の上杉憲勝が上杉謙信の後援により再興をはかったが、まもなく後北条氏に屈服している。
sen.e: For a while, Norikatsu UESUGI of a collateral branch of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family made efforts toward the restoration thereof with the support of Kenshin UESUGI; however, Norikatsu submitted to the Gohojo clan in a little while.

For a while, Norikatsu UESUGI of a collateral branch of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family made efforts toward restoring the line with the support of Kenshin UESUGI; however, Norikatsu submitted to the Gohojo clan after a short time.

For a while, Norikatsu UESUGI of a collateral branch of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family made efforts toward restoring the line with the support of Kenshin UESUGI; however, Norikatsu surrendered to the Gohojo clan after a short time.
sen.cmt: 屈服→降伏と解釈し、submitted to→surrendered toとしました。
